title: CompTIA Network+ N10-009 Practice Quiz 2
description: Test your knowledge of advanced networking concepts from the CompTIA Network+ N10-009 exam.

questions.questionText: Which SDN plane is responsible for managing routing tables and session information?
questions.explanation: The Control Plane manages routing, session tables, and dynamic protocol updates in Software Defined Networking.

questions.questionText: Which protocol would most likely be used to build a secure, encrypted site-to-site VPN between branch offices?
questions.explanation: IPSec with ESP provides both encryption and integrity, making it suitable for secure VPN tunnels.

questions.questionText: A network technician is using Seven Second Subnetting and sees a subnet mask of 255.255.255.224. What is the magic number and how many usable hosts does it provide?
questions.explanation: 255.255.255.224 = /27; magic number is 32, and 2^5 - 2 = 30 usable hosts.

questions.questionText: Which of the following protocols encapsulates data to tunnel it over an IP network, but provides no built-in encryption?
questions.explanation: GRE (Generic Routing Encapsulation) tunnels traffic but does not encrypt it.

questions.questionText: What is the function of a QSFP+ transceiver in a modern network?
options: Combines four 10 Gbit/s links into one transceiver for 40 Gbit/s total
Connects storage devices using block-level access
questions.correctAnswer: Combines four 10 Gbit/s links into one transceiver for 40 Gbit/s total
questions.explanation: QSFP+ supports four 10 Gbit/s channels, delivering up to 40 Gbit/s total bandwidth.

questions.questionText: In a collapsed core network architecture, which of the following is a key trade-off?
options: Separate core and distribution layers for improved isolation
High availability with separate routing and switching
questions.explanation: Collapsed core merges the core and distribution layers to save cost and simplify design, but sacrifices some redundancy.

questions.questionText: Which of the following is a key distinction between NAS and SAN?
options: NAS uses block-level access, SAN uses file-level access
SAN uses block-level access, NAS uses file-level access
Both NAS and SAN are accessed using CIFS
NAS is exclusive to Windows systems
questions.correctAnswer: SAN uses block-level access, NAS uses file-level access
questions.explanation: NAS shares files over the network using file-level protocols, while SAN provides block-level storage for direct access.

questions.questionText: Which wireless encryption method offers forward secrecy and individualized encryption for each session?
questions.explanation: WPA3-SAE (Simultaneous Authentication of Equals) offers improved security with forward secrecy and individualized encryption.

questions.questionText: Which feature of VXLAN enables it to support significantly more logical networks than VLAN?
questions.explanation: VXLAN uses a 24-bit segment ID allowing for over 16 million logical networks, compared to 4096 in VLAN.

questions.questionText: Why might a DNS TTL of 86400 be problematic in a fast-changing web environment?
options: It causes changes to IP address mappings to take up to 24 hours to propagate
It increases the number of DNS queries
questions.correctAnswer: It causes changes to IP address mappings to take up to 24 hours to propagate
questions.explanation: TTL defines how long DNS responses are cached. A value of 86400 seconds (24 hours) delays DNS updates significantly.

questions.questionText: In an IPsec VPN configuration, what function does the Internet Key Exchange (IKE) Phase 1 serve?
options: Transmits encryption keys directly to the peer
Establishes the ESP header for packet encryption
Builds a secure channel for negotiating encryption keys
Authenticates the user to the VPN concentrator
questions.correctAnswer: Builds a secure channel for negotiating encryption keys
questions.explanation: IKE Phase 1 establishes a secure channel using Diffie-Hellman to negotiate encryption keys without transmitting them directly.

questions.questionText: What is the primary difference between IPsec tunnel mode and transport mode?
options: Tunnel mode encrypts only the payload; transport mode encrypts the entire packet
Transport mode adds a new IP header; tunnel mode keeps the original
Tunnel mode encrypts the entire packet including headers; transport mode only encrypts the payload
Transport mode is used for VPNs; tunnel mode is used for LAN communication
questions.correctAnswer: Tunnel mode encrypts the entire packet including headers; transport mode only encrypts the payload
questions.explanation: Tunnel mode adds a new IP header and encrypts the entire original packet; transport mode leaves the IP header intact and only encrypts the payload.

questions.questionText: Which routing protocol uses 'cost' as a metric and is designed to operate within a single autonomous system?
questions.explanation: OSPF (Open Shortest Path First) uses a cost metric based on bandwidth and operates within a single AS as a link-state protocol.

questions.questionText: What does the 'magic number' represent when using magic number subnetting?
options: The number of available host addresses
The interval between subnets in an octet
questions.correctAnswer: The interval between subnets in an octet
questions.explanation: The magic number is the increment value between subnet ranges, calculated as 256 minus the subnet mask's interesting octet.

questions.questionText: Why is the administrative distance important in dynamic routing?
options: It determines the most efficient path within the same protocol
It prioritizes between routes discovered by different protocols
It measures the latency of each path
It calculates the maximum hop count for a route
questions.correctAnswer: It prioritizes between routes discovered by different protocols
questions.explanation: Administrative distance is used to choose between conflicting routes provided by different routing protocols based on trustworthiness.

questions.questionText: Which address type is used in IPv6 to reach the closest instance of a service from multiple endpoints with the same address?
questions.explanation: Anycast allows multiple hosts to share the same address, and data is delivered to the nearest one based on routing metrics.

questions.questionText: In which scenario would you most likely use VLSM (Variable Length Subnet Masking)?
options: When every subnet needs an equal number of hosts
To avoid NAT translation in IPv4 networks
When subnetting networks of different sizes from a single block
To migrate from IPv4 to IPv6
questions.correctAnswer: When subnetting networks of different sizes from a single block
questions.explanation: VLSM allows subnetting a large network into variable-sized subnets, optimizing address allocation.

questions.questionText: Which type of network access control uses IEEE 802.1X for authentication?
questions.explanation: IEEE 802.1X is a port-based NAC method requiring authentication before allowing access to the network.

questions.questionText: Which of the following DNS record types is responsible for specifying the authoritative name server for a domain?
questions.explanation: NS (Name Server) records indicate the authoritative DNS server for the domain.

questions.questionText: What type of firewall rule set behavior assumes all traffic is denied unless explicitly allowed?
questions.explanation: Most firewalls end with an implicit deny rule, blocking all traffic unless a preceding rule allows it.

questions.questionText: Which wireless technology provides simultaneous dual-band support and uses beamforming for better performance?
questions.explanation: 802.11ac supports simultaneous dual-band operation and beamforming to improve performance and range.

questions.questionText: Why is GRE often paired with IPsec in enterprise environments?
options: IPsec does not support multicast traffic
GRE provides encryption while IPsec does not
questions.correctAnswer: IPsec does not support multicast traffic
questions.explanation: IPsec doesn't support multicast, so GRE is used to encapsulate multicast traffic over the tunnel, with IPsec providing encryption.

questions.questionText: In SDN, which plane is responsible for SSH and API-based configuration of devices?
questions.explanation: The Management Plane allows administrative configuration and control via interfaces like SSH and APIs.

questions.questionText: What makes VXLAN more scalable than VLANs for large cloud environments?
options: VXLAN supports over 16 million network segments
VXLAN uses less bandwidth than VLANs
questions.correctAnswer: VXLAN supports over 16 million network segments
questions.explanation: VXLAN uses a 24-bit segment ID (VSID), supporting over 16 million logical networks, compared to VLAN's 4,096 limit.

questions.questionText: Which IPv6 tunneling method embeds an IPv4 address into an IPv6 address to allow transition between protocols?
questions.explanation: 6to4 automatically generates an IPv6 address using the device's IPv4 address and allows IPv6 packets to be routed over IPv4.

questions.questionText: What does the term 'zero trust' imply in modern network security architecture?
options: Users are authenticated once per session
All traffic is considered untrusted by default
Trusted networks are given full access
VPNs are not required inside the LAN
questions.correctAnswer: All traffic is considered untrusted by default
questions.explanation: Zero trust assumes no user or device is inherently trustworthy and requires continuous validation.

questions.questionText: Which command-line tool is most appropriate to verify DNS resolution issues?
questions.explanation: nslookup queries DNS servers to verify if names are resolving to the correct IP addresses.

questions.questionText: Which protocol is used to securely transfer configuration files to a router using SSH?
questions.explanation: SFTP (SSH File Transfer Protocol) provides secure file transfers over SSH, commonly used for router config files.

questions.questionText: What is the purpose of TTL in an IP packet?
options: To limit the lifetime of a DNS record
To track the time since packet creation
questions.explanation: TTL (Time To Live) limits how many hops a packet can make, dropping it if the value reaches zero to avoid endless loops.

questions.questionText: Which type of DNS record is responsible for defining an alias name to a canonical name?
questions.explanation: CNAME records map one domain name to another, serving as an alias.
